Fungal infection.defination: Fungal infection, also known as mycosis, is a disease caused by fungi.Different types are traditionally divided according to the part of the body affected; superficial, subcutaneous, and systemic.Superficial fungal infections include common tinea of the skin, such as tinea of the body, groin, hands, feet and beard, and yeast infections such as pityriasis versicolor
Fungal infection.Other names: Mycoses, fungal disease, fungal infection ICD-10CM codes: Mycoses B35-B49
Fungal infection.Risk factors: Immunodeficiency, cancer treatment, large surface area wounds/burns, organ transplant, COVID-19, tuberculosis
Fungal infection.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, culture, microscopic examination

Allergy.Symptoms: Red eyes, itchy rash, vomiting, runny nose, shortness of breath, swelling, sneezing, and cough.
Allergy.Types: Hay fever, food allergies, atopic dermatitis, allergic asthma, anaphylaxis
Allergy.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, skin prick test, blood test
Allergy.Treatment: Avoiding known allergens, medications, allergen immunotherapy
Allergy.Medication: Steroids, antihistamines, epinephrine, mast cell stabilizers, antileukotrienes
Allergy.Education required:
Doctor of Medicine 
Doctor of Osteopathic medicine 
Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery 
Bachelor of Medicine, Bachelor of Surgery

GERD.Other names: British: Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease ; gastric reflux disease, acid reflux disease, reflux, gastroesophageal reflux
GERD.Symptoms: Taste of acid, heartburn, bad breath, chest pain, breathing problems
GERD.Causes: Inadequate closure of the lower esophageal sphincter
GERD.Risk factors: Obesity, pregnancy, smoking, hiatal hernia, taking certain medicines
GERD.Diagnostic method: Gastroscopy, upper GI series, esophageal pH monitoring, esophageal manometry
GERD.Differential diagnosis: Peptic ulcer disease, esophageal cancer, esophageal spasm, angina
GERD.Medication: Antacids, H2 receptor blockers, proton pump inhibitors, prokinetics

Peptic ulcer disease.Other names: Peptic ulcer, stomach ulcer, gastric ulcer, duodenal ulcer
Peptic ulcer disease.Symptoms: Heartburn, upper abdominal pain,  nausea, belching, vomiting, blood in the stool, weight loss, weight gain, bloating, loss of appetite yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes difficulty swallowing
Peptic ulcer disease.Complications: Bleeding, perforation, ulcer perforation, blockage of the stomach
Peptic ulcer disease.Causes: Helicobacter pylori bacteria, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs , tobacco smoking, Crohn's disease
Peptic ulcer disease.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, confirmed by endoscopy or barium swallow
Peptic ulcer disease.Differential diagnosis: Stomach cancer, coronary heart disease, inflammation of the stomach lining, gallbladder inflammation
Peptic ulcer disease.Treatment: Medications, stopping NSAIDs, stopping smoking, stopping alcohol consumption
Peptic ulcer disease.Medication: Proton pump inhibitor, H2 blocker, antibiotics

AIDS.Symptoms: Early: Flu-like illnessLater: Large lymph nodes, fever, weight loss
AIDS.Risk factors: Unprotected anal or vaginal sex, having another sexually transmitted infection, needle sharing, medical procedures involving unsterile cutting or piercing, and experiencing needlestick injury
AIDS.Prevention: Safe sex, needle exchange, male circumcision, pre-exposure prophylaxis, post-exposure prophylaxis
AIDS.Prognosis: Near normal life expectancy with treatment11 years life expectancy without treatment
AIDS.Frequency: 64.4 million – 113 million total cases1.5 million new cases 38.4 million living with HIV

Diabetes.Symptoms:
Frequent urination
Increased thirst
Increased hunger
Diabetes.Complications:
Metabolic imbalances
Cardiovascular diseases
Nerve and brain damage
Kidney failure
Gastrointestinal changes
Diabetes.Duration: Remission may occur, but diabetes is often life-long
Diabetes.Types:
Type 1 diabetes
Type 2 diabetes
Gestational diabetes
Diabetes.Risk factors:
Type 1: Family history
Type 2: Obesity, lack of exercise, genetics, air pollution

Gastroenteritis.Other names: Gastro, stomach bug, stomach virus, stomach flu, gastric flu, gastrointestinitis
Gastroenteritis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, occasionally stool culture
Gastroenteritis.Differential diagnosis: Inflammatory bowel disease, malabsorption syndrome, lactose intolerance
Gastroenteritis.Prevention: Hand washing, drinking clean water, proper disposal of human waste, breastfeeding

Bronchial Asthma.Symptoms: Recurring episodes of wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, shortness of breath
Bronchial Asthma.Complications: Gastroesophageal reflux disease , sinusitis, obstructive sleep apnea
Bronchial Asthma.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, response to therapy, spirometry

Hypertension.Complications: Coronary artery disease, stroke, heart failure, peripheral arterial disease, vision loss, chronic kidney disease, dementia
Hypertension.Risk factors: Lack of sleep, excess salt, excess body weight, smoking, alcohol, air pollution

Migraine.Symptoms: Headaches, nausea, sensitivity to light, sound, and smell
Migraine.Differential diagnosis: Subarachnoid hemorrhage, venous thrombosis, idiopathic intracranial hypertension, brain tumor, tension headache, sinusitis, cluster headache

Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Other names: Cerebral haemorrhage, cerebral hemorrhage, intra-axial hemorrhage, cerebral hematoma, cerebral bleed, brain bleed
Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Symptoms: Headache, one-sided weakness, vomiting, seizures, decreased level of consciousness, neck stiffness, fever
Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Causes: Brain trauma, aneurysms, arteriovenous malformations, brain tumors
Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Risk factors: High blood pressure, amyloidosis, alcoholism, low cholesterol, blood thinners, cocaine use
Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).Treatment: Blood pressure control, surgery, ventricular drain

Jaundice.Symptoms: Yellowish coloration of skin and sclera, itchiness
Jaundice.Risk factors: Pancreatic cancer, Pancreatitis, Liver disease, Certain infections

Malaria.Complications: seizures, coma, organ failure, anemia, cerebral malaria
Malaria.Diagnostic method: Examination of the blood, antigen detection tests
Malaria.Prevention: Mosquito nets, insect repellent, mosquito control, medications

Chicken pox.Symptoms: Small, itchy blisters, headache, loss of appetite, tiredness, fever

Dengue.Symptoms: Fever, headache, muscle and joint pain, rash
Dengue.Complications: Bleeding, low levels of blood platelets, dangerously low blood pressure
Dengue.Diagnostic method: Detecting antibodies to the virus or its RNA
Dengue.Differential diagnosis: Malaria, yellow fever, viral hepatitis, leptospirosis
Dengue.Prevention: Dengue fever vaccine, decreasing mosquito exposure
Dengue.Treatment: Supportive care, intravenous fluids, blood transfusions

Typhoid.Symptoms:
Fever that starts low and increases daily, possibly reaching as high as 104.9 °F 
Headache, weakness and fatigue, muscle aches, sweating, dry cough, loss of appetite, weight loss, stomach pain, diarrhea or constipation, rash, swollen stomach
Typhoid.Duration: Usually 7–10 days after antibiotic treatment begins. Longer if there are complications or drug resistance.
Typhoid.Causes: Gastrointestinal infection of Salmonella enterica serovar Typhi
Typhoid.Risk factors: Living in or travel to areas where typhoid fever is established, Work as a clinical microbiologist handling Salmonella typhi bacteria, Have close contact with someone who is infected or has recently been infected with typhoid fever, Drink water polluted by sewage that contains Salmonella typhi
Typhoid.Prevention: Preventable by vaccine. Travelers to regions with higher typhoid prevalence are usually encouraged to get a vaccination before travel.
Typhoid.Treatment: Antibiotics, hydration, surgery in extreme cases. Quarantine to avoid exposing others .
Typhoid.Prognosis:
Likely to recover without complications if proper antibiotics administered and diagnosed early. If infecting strain is multi-drug resistant or extensively drug resistant then prognosis more difficult to determine.
Among untreated acute cases, 10% will shed bacteria for three months after initial onset of symptoms, and 2–5% will become chronic typhoid carriers.

Some carriers are diagnosed by positive tissue specimen. Chronic carriers are by definition asymptomatic.

hepatitis A.Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dark urine, jaundice, fever, abdominal pain
hepatitis A.Causes: Eating food or drinking water contaminated with Hepatovirus A infected feces
hepatitis A.Prevention: Hepatitis A vaccine, hand washing, properly cooking food

Hepatitis B.Symptoms: None, yellowish skin, tiredness, dark urine, abdominal pain
Hepatitis B.Usual onset: Symptoms may take up to 6 months to appear
Hepatitis B.Causes: Hepatitis B virus spread by some body fluids
Hepatitis B.Risk factors: Intravenous drug use, sexual intercourse, dialysis, living with an infected person

Hepatitis C.Complications: Liver failure, liver cancer, esophageal and gastric varices
Hepatitis C.Causes: Hepatitis C virus usually spread by blood-to-blood contact
Hepatitis C.Diagnostic method: Blood testing for antibodies or viral RNA

Hepatitis D.Other names: Lábrea's black fever, Lábrea hepatitis, Santa Marta fever

Alcoholic hepatitis.Complications: Cirrhosis, Kidney failure, Confusion, drowsiness and slurred speech , Ascites, Enlarged veins .
Alcoholic hepatitis.Risk factors: Your sex, Obesity, Genetic factors, Race and ethnicity, Binge drinking.

Tuberculosis.Other names: Phthisis, phthisis pulmonalis, consumption, great white plague
Tuberculosis.Symptoms: Chronic cough, fever, cough with bloody mucus, weight loss
Tuberculosis.Diagnostic method: CXR, culture, tuberculin skin test, QuantiFERON
Tuberculosis.Prevention: Screening those at high risk, treatment of those infected, vaccination with bacillus Calmette-Guérin

Common Cold.Other names: Cold, acute viral nasopharyngitis, nasopharyngitis, viral rhinitis, rhinopharyngitis, acute coryza, head cold, upper respiratory tract infection
Common Cold.Symptoms: Cough, sore throat, runny nose, fever
Common Cold.Complications: Usually none, but occasionally otitis media, sinusitis, pneumonia and sepsis can occur
Common Cold.Differential diagnosis: Allergic rhinitis, bronchitis, bronchiolitis, pertussis, sinusitis
Common Cold.Prevention: Hand washing, cough etiquette, social distancing, vitamin C

Pneumonia.Symptoms: Cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, fever
Pneumonia.Risk factors: Cystic fibrosis, COPD, sickle cell disease, asthma, diabetes, heart failure, history of smoking,  very young age, older age
Pneumonia.Differential diagnosis: COPD, asthma, pulmonary edema, pulmonary embolism

Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles).Symptoms: Internal: Painless, bright red rectal bleedingExternal: Pain and swelling around the anus
Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles).Risk factors: Constipation, diarrhea, sitting on the toilet for long periods, pregnancy
Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles).Treatment: Increased fiber, drinking fluids, NSAIDs, rest, surgery

Heart attack.Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, feeling faint, cold sweat, feeling tired; arm, neck, back, jaw, or stomach pain
Heart attack.Complications: Heart failure, irregular heartbeat, cardiogenic shock, cardiac arrest
Heart attack.Risk factors: High blood pressure, smoking, diabetes, lack of exercise, obesity, high blood cholesterol

Varicose veins.Symptoms: None, fullness, pain in the area
Varicose veins.Risk factors: Obesity, not enough exercise, leg trauma, family history, pregnancy

Hypothyroidism.Symptoms: Poor ability to tolerate cold, feeling tired, constipation, weight gain, depression, anxiety, irritability
Hypothyroidism.Complications: During pregnancy can result in cretinism in the baby
Hypothyroidism.Differential diagnosis: Depression, dementia, heart failure, chronic fatigue syndrome

Hyperthyroidism.Symptoms: Irritability, muscle weakness, sleeping problems, fast heartbeat, heat intolerance, diarrhea, enlargement of the thyroid, weight loss
Hyperthyroidism.Causes: Graves' disease, multinodular goiter, toxic adenoma, inflammation of the thyroid, eating too much iodine, too much synthetic thyroid hormone
Hyperthyroidism.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms and confirmed by blood tests

Hypoglycemia.Other names: Hypoglycaemia, hypoglycæmia, low blood glucose, low blood sugar
Hypoglycemia.Symptoms: Headache, blurred vision, shakiness, dizziness, weakness, tiredness, sweating, clamminess, fast heart rate, pounding heartbeat, nervousness or anxiety, hunger, nausea, pins and needles sensation, difficulty talking, confusion, loss of consciousness, unusual behavior, lightheadedness, pale skin color, seizures, death
Hypoglycemia.Causes: Medications , sepsis, kidney failure, certain tumors, liver disease
Hypoglycemia.Diagnostic method: Whipple's triad: Symptoms of hypoglycemia, serum blood glucose level <70 mg/dL , and resolution of symptoms when blood glucose returns to normal
Hypoglycemia.Treatment: Eating foods high in simple sugars, dextrose, glucagon
Hypoglycemia.Frequency: In type 1 diabetics, mild hypoglycemia occurs twice per week on average, and severe hypoglycemia occurs one per year.
Hypoglycemia.Deaths: In type 1 diabetics, 6-10% will die of hypoglycemia.

Osteoarthritis.Other names: Degenerative arthritis, degenerative joint disease, osteoarthrosis
Osteoarthritis.Symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, joint swelling, decreased range of motion
Osteoarthritis.Causes: Connective tissue disease, previous joint injury, abnormal joint or limb development, inherited factors
Osteoarthritis.Risk factors: Overweight, legs of different lengths, job with high levels of joint stress
Osteoarthritis.Diagnostic method: Based on symptoms, supported by other testing
Osteoarthritis.Treatment: Exercise, efforts to decrease joint stress, support groups, pain medications, joint replacement

Arthritis.Symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, redness, swelling, decreased range of motion
Arthritis.Risk factors: Family history, age, sex trait, previous joint injury, obesity.
Arthritis.Treatment: Resting, applying ice or heat, weight loss, exercise, joint replacement

(vertigo) Paroymsal Positional Vertigo.Symptoms: Feeling of spinning or swaying, vomiting, difficulty walking
(vertigo) Paroymsal Positional Vertigo.Causes: Benign paroxysmal positional vertigo , Ménière's disease, vestibular neuritis, stroke, brain tumors, brain injury, multiple sclerosis, migraine

Acne.Symptoms: Blackheads, whiteheads, pimples, oily skin, scarring
Acne.Complications: Anxiety, reduced self-esteem, depression, thoughts of suicide
Acne.Medication: Azelaic acid, benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid, antibiotics, birth control pills, co-cyprindiol, retinoids, isotretinoin

Urinary tract infection.Other names: Acute cystitis, simple cystitis, bladder infection, symptomatic bacteriuria
Urinary tract infection.Symptoms: Pain with urination, frequent urination, feeling the need to urinate despite having an empty bladder
Urinary tract infection.Risk factors: Catheterisation , female anatomy, sexual intercourse, diabetes, obesity, family history
Urinary tract infection.Differential diagnosis: Vulvovaginitis, urethritis, pelvic inflammatory disease, interstitial cystitis, kidney stone disease

Psoriasis.Symptoms: Red , itchy, scaly patches of skin
Psoriasis.Causes: Genetic disease triggered by environmental factors
Psoriasis.Treatment: Steroid creams, vitamin D3 cream, ultraviolet light, Immunosuppressive drugs such as methotrexate

Impetigo.Causes: Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes which spreads by direct contact
Impetigo.Risk factors: Day care, crowding, poor nutrition, diabetes mellitus, contact sports, breaks in the skin
Impetigo.Prevention: Hand washing, avoiding infected people, cleaning injuries
